claim: If you stand close to a microwave, you will get cancer.

supporting.text: Microwaves emit non-ionizing radiation, which lacks sufficient energy to damage DNA or cause cancer, according to scientific consensus.

attacks.text: Microwaves emit non-ionizing radiation, which lacks sufficient energy to damage DNA or cause cancer, according to scientific consensus.
While microwaves emit non-ionizing radiation, prolonged exposure at very close range could theoretically cause thermal tissue damage, which might indirectly increase cancer risk.
Thermal damage from microwaves requires extreme exposure levels far beyond what household microwaves can produce, making this scenario practically impossible under normal use.
Some studies suggest that non-ionizing radiation may have biological effects beyond thermal damage, though the link to cancer remains unproven.
The majority of peer-reviewed research concludes there is no credible evidence linking non-ionizing radiation from microwaves to cancer.

supporting.text: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates microwave ovens to ensure radiation levels remain well below harmful thresholds, making cancer risk negligible.

attacks.text: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates microwave ovens to ensure radiation levels remain well below harmful thresholds, making cancer risk negligible.
Microwave ovens can leak radiation if damaged or poorly maintained, potentially exposing users to higher-than-regulated levels.
FDA regulations require microwave ovens to undergo rigorous testing and include safety mechanisms to prevent radiation leaks even if damaged.
Long-term exposure to even low levels of microwave radiation may have cumulative effects not fully understood by current regulations.
Scientific consensus and decades of research indicate no credible evidence linking microwave radiation at regulated levels to cancer.

supporting.text: Multiple peer-reviewed studies have found no credible evidence linking microwave oven use to increased cancer risk in humans.

attacks.text: Multiple peer-reviewed studies have found no credible evidence linking microwave oven use to increased cancer risk in humans.
Some studies suggest that prolonged exposure to microwave radiation at very close range may have biological effects, though not conclusively linked to cancer.
The biological effects observed in these studies are at radiation levels far higher than what a microwave oven emits, making them irrelevant to typical usage.
The absence of evidence is not evidence of absence; lack of long-term studies on microwave exposure leaves uncertainty.
Regulatory agencies like the FDA and WHO have reviewed decades of research and confirm microwave ovens are safe when used properly.

supporting.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) states that microwave radiation does not have carcinogenic effects when exposure remains within safety standards.

attacks.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) states that microwave radiation does not have carcinogenic effects when exposure remains within safety standards.
Safety standards for microwave radiation exposure may not account for long-term, cumulative effects of low-level exposure.

The WHO's safety standards are based on extensive peer-reviewed research and epidemiological studies, which have not found evidence of carcinogenic effects from microwave radiation within these limits.
Some studies suggest that microwave radiation can cause DNA damage, which is a potential precursor to cancer, even at levels below current safety standards.
The majority of scientific consensus and meta-analyses conclude that microwave radiation at typical exposure levels does not cause DNA damage or increase cancer risk.
